lexUnit.name: value.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: consider to be important or beneficial

sentence.text: They value their architects more for their business demeanours than for their designs , and choose them from a limited number of established companies , more valued for reliability than originality .
They were highly valued for their experience of picketing and organizing processions .
Jane Austen has her abbeys too , but she values them for rather different reasons .
Education is valued , and has always been valued , for its liberating effects .
Intellectual prowess may be valued in the research department , whereas persuasion may be the most valued skill in marketing .
They naturally , therefore , think of God as possessing what they value most in themselves .
Firstly , as we have earlier shown , old people are not valued in the same way as children ; their suffering does not pull at the public heart-strings so strongly .
The peppercorn was valued very highly and was frequently used in trade between the East and the West .
You 're valued in the profession and you know Lottie Langdon always wanted you .
However , I feel sure she values her friendship with me enough to play it our way .
Should the carer feel unsupported personally , or that the cared for person is not valued by other relatives , this again adds to stress .
But AEs who could hard sell were still valued the most in the firm .
We made many friends there , and valued very much the help and inspiration of the beautiful services held every Sunday .
She said : ` We value our former employees very much and every pensioner gets a hamper at Christmas .
Most mahouts , though sadly not all , value their elephants too highly to ill-treat them .
I value my solitude too much . "
Except for marine products , the few goods that polar regions yield are seldom valued highly enough to offset the high costs and risks of exploiting them .
My fish is quite tame and I hand feed him , although as he ( or she ) gets larger I will stop this practice as I value my fingers .
I value their silences and self-expression , but what I miss in their faith is the glorious Anglican tradition of choral services . "
It is particularly important in PSD that students should value the activities and goals of modules they are taking .
He felt as if he had only just remembered , after a long time , why he valued her .
And we have always valued the important contribution made by the churches to our children 's education .
PRINCE CHARLES told yesterday how he valued conversations with the Queen Mother and his late uncle , Lord Mountbatten .
Construction is therefore to be valued ( rather than despised ) for its fruitful possibilities .
Elisabeth valued her consideration .
Dr Burge has valued schemes as a source of research and some universities are now promoting both industrial contact and research experience .
If we value active and exploratory ways of learning we need to provide worthwhile , substantial , clear and well structured representations of ideas for children to explore .
We value our privacy and would rather talk about the weather than enter into controversy or volunteer our innermost thoughts .
The DEPARTMENT values and seeks to develop the skill levels of all staff and aims to provide effective service delivery through a highly motivated , trained and committed staff . "
THE Khmer Rouge values secrecy .
